I am looking into configureWebpack & chainWebpack.

One cool feature of the Vue CLI I found is:
`vue inspect --mode production > wp-prod.js`

This will run through the vue tooling and generate a complete webpack config object, then output it to wp-prod.js!

If you don’t use --mode production, it will default to development.

Also, here’s a good video on Vue CLI and webpack, <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ldXj9wtwyZ4&t=456s>

The first 10 minutes is kind of slow, but then it really takes off.

More feedback on cms-vue-boilerplate.

In real-world apps, you often need vue plugins like Vuex, Vue-Router, or Vuetify.

These plugins now depend on the Vue CLI for ease of use and auto-configuration. Without vue-cli, I think this may be headed for configuration hell!

Hey there Ankit. It’s true to preview and test the content you do need to view in in a HubSpot account. We recommend using a CMS Sandbox account for this.

The HubSpot platform undergoes thousands of updates per day, meaning it would be difficult for you as a developer to ensure you are always using the latest version. ensuring what you saw locally matched what would be in the browser. In-addition the HubSpot platform is very integrated amongst all of the tools. The CRM for example interacts with the CMS and can be used for functionality like Memberships. Serverless functions alone on the CMS can interact with almost every HubSpot product.

Rather than simulate everything and risk inconsistency between the local experience and the web, we’re working on making it easy to build locally but test in the real constantly up-to-date HubSpot environments
